docs.lead_paragraph: It is a mess for which no one wants responsibility.
docs.abstract: The city began using hydraulic pumps to drain more than 150,000 gallons of stagnant water from a mile-long stretch of long-abandoned railroad tracks in the Mott Haven section of the Bronx.
docs.snippet: The city began using hydraulic pumps to drain more than 150,000 gallons of stagnant water from a mile-long stretch of long-abandoned railroad tracks in the Mott Haven section of the Bronx.

docs.lead_paragraph: Fury has been mounting all day on the political left over indications that President Obama may drop a public insurance option from any final health care plan. The outrage may portend the first serious rebellion among liberals against the Obama administration.

headline.main: Liberals Decry Administration's New Stance on Public Insurance

docs.abstract: The White House's apparent retreat from a public insurance plan brought howls from liberal Democrats.
docs.snippet: The White House's apparent retreat from a public insurance plan brought howls from liberal Democrats.

docs.lead_paragraph: Of all the sideshows to the Great 2009 Health Care Debate, the Whole Foods boycott may take the prize as the most unexpected.
docs.abstract: A health care op-ed by the C.E.O. of the food chain is causing some to boycott its stores.
docs.snippet: A health care op-ed by the C.E.O. of the food chain is causing some to boycott its stores.

docs.lead_paragraph: If a public insurance option were to be abandoned, it could be replaced by an alternative favored by some moderates like Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota: the health insurance cooperative. Legislators have not spelled out how these plans might work, but health insurance co-ops do have a history in this country. Anne Underwood, a freelance writer, quizzed Timothy Stoltzfus Jost, a law professor at Washington and Lee University who has written extensively on health care policy, including the feasibility of establishing health insurance co-ops.

headline.main: So What's a Health Insurance Co-op, Anyway?

docs.abstract: Health insurance cooperatives aren't a new idea, but they are now the likeliest alternative to a public insurance option.
docs.snippet: Health insurance cooperatives aren't a new idea, but they are now the likeliest alternative to a public insurance option.

docs.lead_paragraph: Town hall meetings have gotten a bad rap lately, what with the disruptions in the last couple of weeks over health care. And now several senators and members of Congress, most of them Democrats, are refusing the hold them.

headline.main: Gillibrand Opts for Socials and Web Sites Over Town Halls

docs.abstract: Hoping to avoid ugly scenes at town halls, some Democratic senators -- among them New York's Kirsten Gillibrand -- are experimenting with outreach events in other settings.
docs.snippet: Hoping to avoid ugly scenes at town halls, some Democratic senators -- among them New York's Kirsten Gillibrand -- are experimenting with outreach events in other settings.

docs.lead_paragraph: You can agree or not with The New York Times op-ed columnist Paul Krugman's take on the health care debate. But he's worth reading for the primers he provides, along with the polemics. In today's column, Mr. Krugman notes that the combination of publicly supported and private insurance plans that seem a likely outcome of the policymaking in Washington could end up resembling the system in Switzerland:

headline.main: Opinion: The Swiss System and More on Rationing

docs.abstract: New York Times op-ed writers address the Swiss model, rationed care and the dangers of demagoguery.
docs.snippet: New York Times op-ed writers address the Swiss model, rationed care and the dangers of demagoguery.

docs.lead_paragraph: The New York Times reports this morning that the White House seems to be backing away from its insistence that a public insurance option be included in any overhaul of the health care system. The change may answer Republican concerns but is likely to antagonize liberal Democrats. From an article by Sheryl Gay Stolberg:

headline.main: Goodbye to the Public Insurance Option?

docs.abstract: To the likely dismay of liberals, the White House may be softening its insistence on a public insurance plan.
docs.snippet: To the likely dismay of liberals, the White House may be softening its insistence on a public insurance plan.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

headline.main: Insuring Hearts (and Kidneys, Lungs and Livers)

docs.abstract: An economist writes about a gory indicator of inequality in access to health care in the United States: People who lack health insurance are far more likely to donate organs than to receive them.
docs.snippet: An economist writes about a gory indicator of inequality in access to health care in the United States: People who lack health insurance are far more likely to donate organs than to receive them.

headline.main: Young, Mentally Ill and Behind Bars
headline.print_headline: Young, Mentally Ill and Behind Bars

docs.lead_paragraph: Money spent on exorbitant intensive-care medicine for dying, elderly people should be redirected to preventive care for children and mothers.
docs.snippet: Money spent on exorbitant intensive-care medicine for dying, elderly people should be redirected to preventive care for children and mothers.
